p: Lithium metallic foil was used as a counter electrode during electrochemical studies of samples deposited on stainless steel. The current density varied from 10 µA/cm 2 (~0.3C) to 800 µA/cm 2 (~33C) ( Figure 5). It was found that the charging capacities of investigated samples were stable during cycling at a given charge current density. The inset of Figure 5 shows typical charge-discharge curves at a current density of 40 µA/cm 2 (approximately 1C) in the potential range from 0 to 3 V. The main contribution to the capacity during charging/discharging occurred at potentials of 1.5–2.2 V/1.5–0.75 V.
